The concept of the ‘crown’ had evolved over the course of the fourteenth century in an attempt to clarify the king’s position in regards to the law, and particularly to deal with the problem of restraining incompetent or tyrannical kings. McLaren’s revisionist research has produced the most useful modern scholar­ship on the London chronicles. She identifies over forty extant chronicles, but argues for clusters (eight ‘families’), rather than versions of a ‘Main City Chronicle’, as proposed by Charles Kingsford, whose view dominated twentieth-century scholarship. McLaren demonstrates that Kingsford’s approach is untenable, although her own over-simplifies in generalizing the London chronicle as ‘a lay and vernacular voice
